In this study, nickel (Ni)-loaded AFeO3 perovskite catalysts were synthesized with various A-site species (Ca, Ce, and Sr) and utilized them for the hydrogen(H2)-rich syngas production via steam gasification of wood-plastic composites (WPC). To investigate the effect of A-site species (Ca, Ce, and Sr) composition on catalytic properties, the catalysts were tested under reaction conditions of 800 °C and a catalyst-to-feedstock (C/F) ratio of 0.1. 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 indicated the highest gas yield (68.32 wt%) and H2 selectivity (53.91 vol%). These results are attributed to its excellent oxygen storage capacity (OSC) associated with the Ce4 + /Ce3+ redox pair, high lattice oxygen mobility, and strong metal–support interaction. These properties effectively promoted tar cracking and H2 production through reforming and surface redox reactions. In addition, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 was tested at various temperatures (700, 750, and 800 °C), C/Fs (0.05, 0.1, and 0.2) and catalyst conditions (fresh and regenerated). An increase in the gasification temperature from 700 °C to 800 °C improved both gas yield and H2 selectivity. Furthermore, at a C/F ratio of 0.2, the maximum gas yield (74.99 wt%) and H2 selectivity (57.94 vol%) were achieved. The findings of this study demonstrate that 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 (A = Ca, Ce, and Sr) catalysts possess considerable potential for efficient H2 production and stable performance in the steam gasification of WPC. Graphical Abstract Keywords Steam gasification Ni-loaded catalyst Perovskite oxide H2-generation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The continued generation of municipal solid wastes, driven by rapid industrialization, urbanization, and shifting consumption patterns, has emerged as a significant challenge, leading to resource depletion and environmental degradation. Among these wastes, wood–plastic composites (WPC) are increasingly produced owing to their high demand in various industries for mechanical strength and durability [1–3]. However, with repeated reuse, WPC gradually lose their mechanical properties and are ultimately disposed of through incineration or landfilling. Existing inefficient waste treatment methods are major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions and ecosystem degradation, highlighting the urgent need for sustainable and efficient alternatives. Therefore, developing sustainable technological approaches for the environmentally safe disposal of end-of-life WPC is essential. In particular, the conversion of WPC into high value-added energy and chemicals has recently attracted considerable attention as a promising strategy. In this regard, thermochemical processes have been actively studied in recent years, with a focus on their sustainability and technical efficiency [4–6]. Among these, gasification is particularly attractive, as it converts waste into high-calorific syngas, thereby enabling efficient energy recovery [7,8]. Steam gasification, in particular, is regarded as a relatively economical process that employs steam as the gasifying agent and produces syngas with a higher H2 content than air- or oxygen-based gasification [9–11]. However, tar formation remains a major technical challenge in reliably producing high-quality H2 [12,13]. Tar consists of condensable organic compounds (e.g., heavy hydrocarbons), which readily form in low-temperature zones during gasification. It causes serious operational issues, such as pipeline clogging and reduced energy recovery efficiency [14,15]. To address this challenge, catalytic conversion has emerged as an effective approach for transforming tar compounds into light gases through mechanisms such as reforming, cracking, hydrogenation, and selective oxidation [16–18]. To produce tar-free, high-quality syngas, catalysts must exhibit high reactivity, thermal and structural stability, tar-suppression capability, and resistance to coke formation [19,20]. To meet these requirements, various types of catalysts have been investigated [21,22], including natural minerals (e.g., dolomite, olivine) [23], alkali- and alkaline earth metals in oxide form [24,25], nickel(Ni)-based catalysts [26,27], zeolites [28], and carbon materials [29]. Among them, Ni-based catalysts have attracted significant attention as the most promising option for steam gasification due to their high reforming activity, excellent tar removal and H2 generation capabilities, and relatively low cost [30–32]. However, Ni-based catalysts still face rapid activity degradation and eventual deactivation during long-term operation, due to coke deposition, accumulation of polymer-derived carbon species, and sintering of Ni particles at high temperatures [33]. Recent studies have therefore focused on modifying the structural and chemical characteristics of Ni-based catalysts to enhance coke resistance and long-term stability [34,35]. In particular, supports with high oxygen mobility and oxygen storage capacity (OSC) can enhance catalytic activity, stability, and coke resistance by supplying mobile oxygen species during reforming reactions and promoting carbon removal from Ni surfaces [36]. In this context, perovskites have emerged as promising support materials for improving the durability and operational stability of Ni-loaded catalysts [37]. This structure provides high thermal stability, sintering inhibition of metal particles, and promotes formation and mobility of oxygen vacancies, thereby reducing carbon deposition and enhancing activity in gasification and reforming reactions [38,39]. Therefore, when perovskites serve as supports for Ni-loaded catalysts, the enhanced Ni particle dispersibility leads to increased catalytic activity and improved H2 production selectivity [40]. Moreover, introducing Fe at the B-site is effective in creating oxygen vacancies (δ), improving oxygen mobility, and modifying electronic structure, thereby increasing surface active sites [41,42]. In particular, A-site substitution with vacancy-promoting metals significantly boosts lattice oxygen mobility and reactivity, which facilitates CO adsorption and oxidation. This plays a key role in enhancing H2 production during water–gas shift (CO + H2O ⇌ CO2 + H2), steam reforming (CnHm + n H2O → n CO + (n + m/2) H2), and dry reforming (CnHm + n CO2 →2 n CO + m/2 H2) processes [43,44]. Accordingly, AFeO3 perovskite catalysts are expected to simultaneously enhance catalyst stability and H2 generation performance in gasification and reforming processes. Indeed, Li et al. [45] also demonstrated that the multivalent oxidation state transition (Fe2+/Fe3+/Fe4+) at B-site Fe in LaFeO3 promote lattice oxygen release and vacancy formation, key factors in achieving high gas yields during biomass reforming and CO2/H2O decomposition. Perovskite-based catalysts have been widely investigated in various thermochemical conversion processes; however, their application as supports for Ni-loaded catalysts in gasification-based H2 production remains very limited. In particular, systematic studies employing the AFeO3 structure with Fe at the B-site are scarcely reported. In this study, 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 (A= Ca, Ce, and Sr) catalysts were synthesized, and applied to WPC steam gasification for producing H2-rich syngas. By substituting different metal cations at the A-site, the effects of A-site composition on H2 production, tar conversion efficiency, and catalyst thermal stability were comparatively analyzed. Additionally, the perovskite catalysts were also compared with commercial 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 to evaluate their catalytic performance. This study investigated H2 production through steam gasification of WPC using Ni-loaded perovskite catalysts. In addition, the impact of key reaction parameters, including temperature, catalyst-to-feedstock (C/F) ratio, and catalyst conditions was assessed. This study highlights the potential of 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 (A = Ca, Ce, Sr) perovskite catalysts as an efficient and sustainable approach for converting waste-derived materials such as WPC into valuable syngas. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Wood-plastic composites In this study, WPC, purchased from a domestic manufacturer, was used to produce H2-rich gas. Prior to the experiments, the WPC samples were dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The WPC sample was composed mainly of wood components (42 %), followed by mixed plastics (PE and PP, 34 %), CaCO3 (14 %), and other additives (10 %). Table 1 presents the proximate and ultimate analyses of the WPC sample. 2.2 Catalyst preparation and characterization Ni-loaded catalysts were prepared via the wet impregnation method on each support. For the conventional 10 wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, γ-Al2O3 was stirred in an aqueous solution of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate for 1 h (at room temperature) to achieve homogeneous Ni dispersion. The synthesized catalyst was dried at 110 °C for 12 h, calcined at 550 °C for 3 h, and finally reduced under H2 at 750 °C for 3 h. 10 wt% Ni-loaded AFeO3 perovskite catalysts (10 wt% Ni/AFeO3, where A= Ca, Ce, and Sr) were prepared using a two-step process. To synthesize CaFeO3 via the sol-gel combustion method, the calcium nitrate nanohydrate and Iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate were dissolved in deionized water, seperately. The metal nitrate solutions were mixed with glycerin, serving as a fuel, at a metals-to-fuel molar ratio of 2.5:20 to promote homogeneous gel formation during the combustion-assisted sol–gel process. Subsequently, ammonia solution was added to adjust the pH to 10. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 8 h and calcined at 750°C for 3 h. Two additional perovskite catalysts, CeFeO3 and SrFeO3, were prepared using cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate and strontium nitrate as the respective A-site precursors, following the same synthesis procedure. In the subsequent step, 10 wt% Ni (based on total mass) was loaded onto the synthesized perovskite supports. The resulting samples were dried and then calcined. Finally, the catalysts underwent a reduction treatment under a H2 atmosphere at 750 °C for 2 h. The physicochemical properties of the prepared catalysts were determined using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), hydrogen-chemisorption (H2-chemisorption). Detailed descriptions of these procedures are provided in the Supplementary Materials. 2.3 Steam gasification setup In this study, steam gasification of WPC was carried out in a laboratory-scale reactor system consisting of three main components: a control unit, a gasification reaction unit, and a product condensation-collection unit ( Fig. 1). Within the gasification reaction unit, the reaction section contained two reactors (R1 and R2), each surrounded by separate furnaces. R1 (I.D. ½-inch) was loaded with 3 g of WPC, while R2 (¼-inch) contained 0.3 g of catalyst, reflecting the respective sample loads. To perform gasification, furnace temperature controllers were set to 800 °C. During the heat up, nitrogen (N2, 20 mL min-1) was injected to purge continuously. Once the temperature reached 800 °C, the furnace was placed over reactor to perform the gasification reaction. During gasification, steam and N2 were introduced at flow rates of 1 mL/min and 50 mL/min, respectively, using a syringe pump and a mass-flow controller. All reactions were carried out for 15 min. Condensed tar and water were collected at the bottom of the condenser, and the product gas was collected in Tedlar bag for analysis. Steam gasification of WPC was performed over 10 wt% Ni-loaded perovskite catalysts (10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3, 10 wt% Ni/SrFeO3) at various temperatures (700, 750, and 800 °C) and catalyst-to-feedstock (C/F) ratios of 0.05, 0.1, and 0.2. To evaluate the H2 production performance of the perovskite catalysts, 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 was also tested under the same conditions. The concentrations of major gas species (H2, CO, CO2, and CH4) were quantified using a gas chromatograph (Agilent 8890) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In addition, hydrocarbon compounds (≥ CH4) were detected using a separate GC system (Agilent 7890B) fitted with a flame ionization detector (FID). All chromatographic data were processed and analyzed using Instrument 1 software. Details on the determination of gasification products are provided in the Supplementary Materials. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of perovskite catalyst 3.1.1 Brunauer-Emmett-Teller analysis Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis was employed to evaluate the surface area and pore characteristics of Ni-loaded perovskite catalysts. As shown in Table 2, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 exhibited the highest specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter compared to the other catalysts. These properties are expected to enhance catalytic performance by facilitating gas diffusion, improving mass transfer, providing better access to active sites, and ultimately reducing coke formation during gasification [46]. Upon Ni impregnation, all catalysts exhibited an overall reduction in pore characteristics, likely due to partial pore blockage caused by Ni particles penetrating the internal channels during the impregnation process [47]. To further evaluate their structural stability under reaction conditions, the textural properties of the spent catalysts were also summarized in Table 2. Only minor variations were observed compared with the fresh samples, indicating that the catalysts preserved their structural integrity during the gasification reaction. In particular, the 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst exhibited remarkable stability, maintaining effective pore accessibility throughout the reaction. The retention of pore accessibility is a critical factor for catalyst stability, as it mitigates common deactivation pathways such as pore blockage, structural collapse, and excessive sintering. Sustained pore accessibility ensures continuous diffusion of reactants to the active sites, thereby promoting higher and more stable reaction rates. Moreover, comparison with the spent 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 and 10 wt% Ni/SrFeO3 catalysts suggests that the 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst demonstrates superior thermal resistance. This can be attributed to its greater resistance to high-temperature sintering, which is a known cause of surface area loss and activity decline in catalysts. Overall, the results highlight that the structural stability and preserved pore architecture of 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 directly support the maintenance of surface area, active site availability, and reactant accessibility—factors that collectively underpin its high and sustained catalytic performance in the gasification process. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction To evaluate the crystallinity of the synthesized Ni-loaded perovskite catalysts, XRD patterns are presented in Fig. 2. The diffraction patterns of CeFeO3 (JCPDS: 080045), SrFeO3 (JCPDS:00400905), and CaFeO3 (JCPDS: 41–0753) exhibit distinct reflections at characteristic 2θ values, which are consistent with the reported reference data, confirming the successful synthesis of these perovskite oxides (Fig. 2(a)). Distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° correspond to metallic Ni, confirming its presence within the catalyst structure [45]. Among the samples, 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 exhibited the most intense Ni peaks, suggesting the presence of relatively large and well-crystallized Ni particles (Fig. 2(b)). In contrast, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 displayed broader and less intense Ni peaks, indicating smaller crystallites and improved dispersion of Ni particles. According to the Scherrer equation [48], the average crystallite sizes of Ni in the catalysts followed the order: 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 (11.2 nm) < 10 wt% Ni/SrFeO3 (12.8 nm) < 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 (13.1 nm). Compared with the Sr- and Ca- substituted perovskites, the incorporation of Ce effectively suppresses Ni crystallite growth by promoting higher dispersion and stabilization of smaller Ni nanoparticles on the support. This enhanced dispersion is closely associated with an increased number of catalytically active sites, improved thermal stability, and greater resistance to carbon deposition [49]. Consequently, the superior dispersion of Ni on perovskite-type supports is expected to contribute to higher catalytic activity and improved gasification performance [50]. Fig. 2(c) shows the XRD pattern of the used catalysts. The absence of NiO peaks after the reaction and the preservation of the characteristic diffraction peaks of metallic Ni suggest that the crystal structure of the active metallic Ni remained stable. However, a slight decrease in the intensity of the Ni0 peaks was observed in the used catalyst; this decrease is more plausibly attributed to the partial encapsulation of Ni by the support [51]. In addition, the gasification conditions (high temperature and reducing/steam environment) induce mainly surface or near-surface changes in the perovskite structure. Specifically, steam at elevated temperature can remove oxygen from the lattice (AFeO3 → AFeO3-δ), leading to oxygen vacancy formation and partial reduction of B-site cations. These processes cause slight lattice distortions, such as contraction or expansion, which are reflected in small 2θ shifts, peak broadening due to microstrain, and the appearance of minor additional peaks. Nevertheless, the bulk perovskite framework remains intact, and XRD patterns of the spent catalysts therefore exhibit only subtle modifications rather than a complete phase transformation. This observation underscores the structural robustness of the catalyst and its resistance to significant deactivation, which is advantageous for sustained performance in gasification reactions 3.1.3 H2-temperature programmed reduction H2-TPR analysis was employed to examine the reducibility and metal–support interactions of 10 wt% Ni-loaded catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the TPR profiles clearly demonstrate that the reducibility of Ni is significantly affected by the type of A-site cation in the perovskite support. The peaks observed between 250 °C and 380 °C are designated as region α, corresponding to the reduction of free NiO particles on the surface of the support. The peak observed between 450 °C and 600 °C is designated as region β, corresponding to the reduction of Ni oxides to Ni metal that exhibit weak interactions with the support. In contrast, the peaks appearing between 700 °C and 800 °C are assigned to region γ, which is attributed to the reduction of Ni oxides strongly interacting with the support. Notably, the 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst exhibits a significant shift of reduction peaks toward lower temperatures, suggesting enhanced reducibility [52]. This behavior is attributed to the high OSC and excellent redox properties of 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3, which facilitate easier reduction of NiO. The dynamic Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycle contributes to the release of lattice oxygen, thereby promoting the reduction process [53,54]. In contrast, the 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 and 10 wt% Ni/SrFeO3 catalysts show reduction peaks at higher temperatures, indicating lower oxygen mobility and weaker redox activity. These results indicate that the reducibility of Ni species is strongly governed by the oxygen mobility, redox behavior, and the strength of metal–support interactions, all of which are influenced by the nature of the A-site cation in the perovskite structure. The high-temperature reduction peak associated with the undesirable NiAl2O4 spinel phase was observed at 850°C for the 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst [55], whereas this phase was absent in the 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3(A= Ca, Ce, and Sr). Suppressing NiAl2O4 formation is essential. Since metallic Ni is the active phase in most Ni-catalyzed reactions (e.g., steam gasification), the formation of NiAl2O4 lowers the number of available active sites. This can severely reduce catalytic performance, particularly in reactions requiring high dispersion and accessibility of Ni [56]. 3.1.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS is an effective method for probing surface elemental composition and species in catalysts. As shown in Figs. 4(a), 4(e) and 4(i), the peak of Ni 2p spectra of all catalysts exhibits two main peaks at binding energies of approximately 872 and 854 eV, accompanied by satellite peaks around 879 and 861 eV, which are attributed to Ni oxide and hydroxide species [57]. The Fe 2p spectra of each catalyst (Figs. 4(b), 4(f), and 4(j)) display two major peaks, Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2. The Fe 2p3/2peak primarily appears between 711.5 and 710.5 eV, indicating Fe3+ oxidation states; satellite peaks around 719–718 eV provide further confirmation of Fe3+ [52]. The XPS spectra in Figs. 5(c), 5(g), and 5(k) indicate that Ca, Ce, and Sr exist in multiple oxidation states within their respective perovskite oxide structures. Figs. 4(d), 4(h), and 4(l) show the O 1 s spectra of the 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 (A = Ca, Ce, and Sr) catalysts. Each spectrum reveals two deconvoluted peaks: one at ≈ 531 eV, attributed to adsorbed oxygen species (O_ads), and another at ≈ 529 eV, attributed to lattice oxygen (O_latt) [58]. The relative concentration of surface O_ads decreases in the order 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 (0.86) > 10 wt% Ni/SrFeO3 (0.84) > 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 (0.61), indicating that 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 possesses the highest density of surface oxygen vacancies, while 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 retains more lattice oxygen [59]. The 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst exhibits a relatively high concentration of lattice oxygen along with a certain amount of oxygen vacancies. The abundant and highly mobile lattice oxygen effectively replenishes surface oxygen species consumed during gasification reactions, thereby maintaining continuous catalytic activity. In addition, it acts as a stable oxygen reservoir under high-temperature conditions, facilitating the direct oxidation of carbon deposits (coke) and enabling in situ regeneration of active catalytic sites. This redox capability not only mitigates catalyst deactivation due to coking but also promotes long-term stability and sustained H2 production during gasification processes [60,61]. 3.1.5 H 2 -chemisorption To evaluate the Ni dispersion and surface area of 10 wt% Ni-loaded catalysts, H2-chemisorption measurements were conducted, as shown in Table 3. Ni dispersion is defined as the ratio between the amount of Ni exposed on the catalyst surface and the total Ni content in the catalyst. Generally, higher Ni dispersion and larger surface area lead to increased catalytic activity [62]. Among the Ni-loaded perovskite catalysts, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 exhibited the highest Ni dispersion and surface area, while 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 showed the lowest values. These results are consistent with the BET surface area (Table 2), suggesting that a larger surface area of the support tends to promote Ni exposure on the surface, which results in higher Ni dispersion and greater Ni surface area [63]. In particular, the CeFeO3 catalyst appears to facilitate the reduction of Ni due to its high oxygen mobility and redox properties, leading to greater exposure of Ni0 species on the surface. In contrast, the CaFeO3 support exhibited strong metal-support interactions that suppressed the exposure of Ni0 species, resulting in the lowest adsorption capacity and surface area, whereas CeFeO3 allows for significantly higher availability of Ni. Therefore, in the steam gasification reaction, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 is expected to exhibit higher activity due to the presence of more active Ni0 sites, while 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 may show lower reforming activity but could offer advantages in terms of structural stability. 3.2 Catalytic gasification of Ni-loaded perovskite catalysts 3.2.1 Yield of different products Fig. 5(a) presents the product yields from steam gasification of WPC conducted at 800 °C with a C/F ratio of 0.1, using 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 and Ni-loaded perovskite catalysts. In the presence of a catalyst, gas production increased while tar formation decreased compared with the non-catalytic reaction, clearly demonstrating the effectiveness of the catalysts in terms of syngas production. In the case of gas yield, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 as catalyst produced the highest amount (66.89 wt%), followed by 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 (66.22 wt%) > 10 wt% Ni/SrFeO3 (63.98 wt%) > 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 (58.19 wt%) > non-catalytic (47.22 wt%). In contrast, the tar yield was highest for the non-catalytic reaction and lowest for 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 (20.45 wt%). This trend can be attributed to the smaller Ni particle size observed in the perovskite-supported catalysts, particularly in the 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst. Smaller Ni particles possess a higher surface area-to-volume ratio, which increases the exposure of surface Ni atoms, the catalytically active species. This leads to a greater density of active sites available for gasification reactions, thereby accelerating reaction kinetics and improving the conversion efficiency of carbonaceous feedstocks. Additionally, the increased exposure of reactive sites, such as step and corner atoms, enables more efficient activation of CH4 molecules through C–H bond cleavage [64]. Improved dispersion of Ni particles also retards carbon nucleation on individual particles, effectively suppressing coke formation. This favors gas-phase reactions over carbon deposition, thereby extending the catalyst’s operational lifetime. Furthermore, smaller Ni particles enhance redox cycling between Ni0 and Ni2+, especially when supported on oxygen-conductive materials like perovskites. The improved mobility of lattice oxygen facilitates the oxidation of deposited carbon and the continuous regeneration of active sites, sustaining catalytic performance during steam gasification or partial oxidation processes [65]. In case of char, it remained relatively constant in the range of 11.00–12.00 wt% likely due to stronger dependence on reaction temperature than types of catalysts. When comparing 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 and 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 (A= Ca, Ce, and Sr), the 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 systems showed improved gas yield along with reduced coke and tar formation. Generally, during WPC gasification, insufficient availability of mobile oxygen limits partial oxidation of carbon, leading to coke deposition on the catalyst. However, when perovskites are used as catalysts, their intrinsic oxygen transport and lattice oxygen supply capabilities promote the oxidation of carbon and hydrocarbon fragments on the catalyst surface, effectively mitigating coke formation [44]. This is because the lattice oxygen in the perovskite support readily oxidizes C and CHn species adsorbed on metal particles, accelerating the reaction rate and facilitating the removal of deposited carbon [66]. Furthermore, Takehira et al. [67] demonstrated that perovskite catalysts exhibit high H2 productivity and coke resistance in CH4 partial oxidation, owing to the high mobility of lattice oxygen and the uniform dispersion of Ni particles. This behavior is attributed to the transfer of mobile oxygen from the perovskite structure to metallic Ni, contributing to efficient coke removal. 3.2.2 Composition of gaseous products The gaseous product composition from WPC steam gasification at 800 °C (C/F = 0.1) using 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 and perovskite catalysts is shown in Fig. 5(b). When comparing the non-catalytic case with the 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3, the selectivity of H2 significantly increases from 25.12 vol% to 32.91 vol%, and CO also rises from 11.04 vol% to 17.58 vol%, while CO2, CH4, and C2–C4 components decreased. This improvement can be attributed to the presence of metallic Ni, which facilitates steam reforming reactions of methane and tar, as well as surface redox reactions. Additionally, the catalyst promotes tar decomposition, which likely contributes to the observed enhancement in H2 yield [68]. The introduction of 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 catalysts led to a further substantial increase in H2 yield. Among all catalysts, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 showed the highest H2 selectivity (53.91 vol%), followed by 10 wt% Ni/CaFeO3 (50.67 vol%) > 10 wt% Ni/SrFeO3 (46.10 vol%) > 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 (32.91 vol%), with a similar trend noted for CO. In contrast, CO2, CH4, and C2–C4 gases exhibited opposite behavior. These results indicate that the 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 catalysts outperform 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalysts in promoting H2 evolution reactions due to their superior OSC, lattice oxygen mobility, and strong metal–support interactions, which facilitate reforming reactions and surface redox processes. Supporting this, Valizadeh et al. [69] reported significantly higher gas yields and H2 selectivity during steam gasification using Ni/perovskite catalysts compared to Ni/Al2O3. The improved H2 selectivity is attributed to perovskite-supported catalysts results not only from the enhanced activity of metallic Ni but also from the structural and chemical advantages provided by the perovskites, which effectively promote the catalytic performance of Ni during WPC steam gasification [70]. The perovskite support offers high structural stability and excellent Ni dispersion due to its inherent high porosity and diverse cationic composition, as demonstrated by XRD and BET analyses, which revealed reduced Ni crystallite size and improved metal dispersion. Additionally, H2-TPR analysis confirmed the enhanced Ni–support interactions in perovskite-based catalysts, which increased the availability of active metal sites and significantly contributed to the improved gasification rate and H2 production performance [71]. These features also help inhibit the sintering and abrasion of Ni metal particles even at elevated temperatures, which correlates with the reduced coke formation observed in the catalytic experiments. The 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst exhibited the highest gas yield and H2 selectivity among all tested catalysts. This performance is primarily attributed to the uniform dispersion of metallic Ni on the catalyst surface, which effectively promoted H2 production reactions. In particular, Fe located at the B-site contributed to the activation of oxidative reforming reactions by facilitating the involvement of lattice oxygen either directly or indirectly in the reaction, thereby enhancing H2 production. Moreover, the incorporation of Ce at the A-site led to an increase in oxygen vacancy concentration, which further improved Ni dispersion, suppressed carbon deposition, and enhanced both the activity and durability of the catalyst. As a result, the CeFeO3-based perovskite, owing to its excellent oxygen-supplying capacity, effectively contributed to oxygen transfer and the provision of reactive oxygen species during the reaction, significantly improving overall gasification performance. Yang et al. [72] investigated La1-XCeXNiO3 (X = 0–0.5) perovskite-based catalysts in steam and CO2 reforming of methane. Their study demonstrated that partial substitution of La with Ce at the A-site improved the reducibility of Ni species and increased the number of active sites, thereby enhancing H2 production efficiency and catalyst stability. Similarly, Sierra et al. [73] synthesized perovskites of the type La1-XAXNiO3 (A = Pr, Ce) and evaluated them in dry methane reforming. Their results confirmed that Ce substitution at the A-site significantly improved the reducibility and dispersion of Ni, leading to increased H2 yield and enhanced catalyst lifetime through improved coke resistance. 3.3 Effect of reaction temperatures To evaluate the effect of reaction temperature, steam gasification of WPC was carried out at different temperatures (700, 750, 800 °C) using 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst with a C/F ratio of 0.1 ( Fig. 6(a-b)). As shown in Fig. 6(a), increasing the temperature from 700 °C to 800 °C resulted in a rise in gas yield from 56.36 wt% to 68.32 wt%. Conversely, oil yield decreased from 29.64 wt% to 20.35 wt%, indicating that higher gasification temperatures favor gas production. This trend reflects the enhanced hydrocarbon cracking and reforming reactions at elevated temperatures. Char yield also tended to decline with increasing temperature. Fig. 6(b) demonstrates the influence of reaction temperature on syngas composition. H2 selectivity increased significantly with temperature, peaking at 53.91 vol% at 800 °C compared to 39.19 vol% at 700 °C. CO selectivity also rose, reaching 25.57 vol% at 800 °C. In contrast, CO2, CH4, and C2–C4 concentrations decreased with higher temperatures. These results are consistent with the steam gasification reaction being intrinsically an endothermic process, which accelerates under high-temperature conditions in accordance with Le Chatelier’s principle, shifting the reaction equilibrium toward heat-absorbing reforming pathways. Consequently, high temperatures promote hydrocarbon cracking, char gasification, steam and dry reforming of methane, and the Boudouard reaction (C + CO2 ↔ 2CO) [74,75]. On the other hand, the exothermic water–gas shift reaction is relatively suppressed. This combination of reaction behavior explains the increased yields of H2 and CO at elevated temperatures, accompanied by reduced CH4 and heavy hydrocarbon residues. Similarly, Cao et al. [76] conducted catalyst-assisted steam gasification of wood chips under various temperatures, reporting that H2 selectivity increased substantially from 37.2 vol% at 700 °C to 51.1 vol% at 850 °C, while CO2 and CH4 decreased. These findings are consistent with the trends observed in this study. 3.4 Effect of C/F ratios In Figs. 6(c) and 6(d), the activity of the 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst in WPC steam gasification at 800 °C was evaluated under various C/F ratios (0.05, 0.1, and 0.2) As illustrated in Fig. 6(c), as the C/F ratio increased from 0.05 to 0.2, the gas yield tended to increase to 60.41, 68.32, and 74.99 wt%, while the tar yield decreased. For the coke yield, a decreasing trend was seen as the C/F ratio increased, with char being produced in a similar range of 10.67 wt% to 11.33 wt% under the same temperature conditions. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the selectivity of H2 increased significantly with an increase in the C/F ratio from 0.05 to 0.2, ranging from 42.03 vol% to 57.94 vol%, confirming the trend of increasing H2 selectivity with increasing catalyst amount. Similarly, the selectivity of CO also increased as the C/F ratio increased, while the selectivity of CO2, CH4, and C2-C4 decreased. These trends are attributed to the fact that lower catalyst loading reduces the number of active sites accessible for reaction, which limits high-temperature reforming reactions such as steam reforming, dry reforming, and cracking [77]. In particular, at lower C/F ratios, reduced contact time with Ni active sites significantly hampers reforming reactions, diminishing C–C and C–H bond activation [46]. It is noteworthy that overall, the H2 and CO selectivity increased significantly when the C/F ratio was increased from 0.05 to 0.1, but the change was relatively insignificant when it was increased from 0.1 to 0.2. A similar observation was reported by Wu et al. [78], suggesting that beyond a certain level of catalyst loading, additional active sites do not substantially enhance reaction rates or efficiency. In other words, at a C/F ratio of 0.1, a sufficient number of Ni active sites are already available to promote nearly complete reaction, and additional catalyst addition yields diminishing returns. 3.5 Catalyst regeneration test Catalysts gradually deactivate during repeated use; therefore, evaluating their regeneration performance for reuse is an important task. In this study, the spent 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst was regenerated by heating in air to 550 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and calcining for 3 h to remove deposited coke, followed by H2 reduction at 750 °C for 3 h. The regenerated catalyst was then applied to the gasification reaction to evaluate its reusability ( Fig. 7). Fig. 7(a) compares the product yields obtained from gasification using the fresh and regenerated catalysts. The gas yield obtained with the fresh catalyst was 68.32 wt%, while that with the regenerated catalyst was 67.20 wt%, showing negligible difference. Similarly, the tar yield remained almost unchanged, from 20.35 wt% with the fresh catalyst to 21.53 wt% with the regenerated catalyst. These results indicate that the active metallic phase and structural integrity of the catalyst were well preserved after the regeneration process. Fig. 7(b) presents the syngas composition as a function of regeneration. The H2 selectivity slightly decreased from 53.91 vol% with the fresh catalyst to 52.56 vol% with the regenerated catalyst, whereas the CO selectivity increased from 25.57 vol% to 27.78 vol%. Overall, the syngas composition showed no significant difference between the two catalysts. These findings demonstrate that the regeneration process effectively suppressed deactivation and structural changes, enabling the catalyst to maintain stable performance even after repeated use. A similar observation was reported by Barbarias et al. [79], who investigated Ni-based catalysts over five consecutive reaction–regeneration cycles and reported that the H2 concentration decreased only slightly, from 69.6 % to 68.0 %, while CO2 concentration decreased by 4.4 % and CO concentration varied by only 0.5 % across the cycles. These studies are consistent with the present findings, confirming that the regeneration process allows catalysts to retain their activity and structural stability during repeated use. 4 Conclusion In this study, Ni-loaded catalysts were designed using AFeO3-type perovskite oxides with various A-site metals (Ca, Ce, and Sr) as supports and applied to the steam gasification of WPC for efficient production of H2-rich syngas. Experimental results demonstrated that the 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 catalysts exhibited superior gas yields and H2 selectivity compared to the commercial 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Among them, the 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 catalyst showed the highest gas yield (68.32 wt%) and H2 selectivity (53.91 vol%). These improvements are attributed to the OSC enabled by the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycle, enhanced lattice oxygen mobility, and excellent Ni dispersion and sintering resistance. These factors synergistically promoted tar reforming and H2-producing reactions, such as steam reforming and methane reforming. Furthermore, H2 selectivity increased with rising reaction temperature, and performance evaluation under different C/F ratios revealed maximum results at C/F = 0.2 (74.99 wt% gas yield and 57.94 vol% H2 selectivity). These findings confirm that 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 catalysts with precisely controlled A-site composition offer a promising catalytic system for the high-efficiency steam gasification of WPC and represent a viable strategy for advancing sustainable H2 production technologies. coredata.dc:description: In this study, nickel (Ni)-loaded AFeO3 perovskite catalysts were synthesized with various A-site species (Ca, Ce, and Sr) and utilized them for the hydrogen(H2)-rich syngas production via steam gasification of wood-plastic composites (WPC). To investigate the effect of A-site species (Ca, Ce, and Sr) composition on catalytic properties, the catalysts were tested under reaction conditions of 800 °C and a catalyst-to-feedstock (C/F) ratio of 0.1. 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 indicated the highest gas yield (68.32 wt%) and H2 selectivity (53.91 vol%). These results are attributed to its excellent oxygen storage capacity (OSC) associated with the Ce4 + /Ce3+ redox pair, high lattice oxygen mobility, and strong metal–support interaction. These properties effectively promoted tar cracking and H2 production through reforming and surface redox reactions. In addition, 10 wt% Ni/CeFeO3 was tested at various temperatures (700, 750, and 800 °C), C/Fs (0.05, 0.1, and 0.2) and catalyst conditions (fresh and regenerated). An increase in the gasification temperature from 700 °C to 800 °C improved both gas yield and H2 selectivity. Furthermore, at a C/F ratio of 0.2, the maximum gas yield (74.99 wt%) and H2 selectivity (57.94 vol%) were achieved. The findings of this study demonstrate that 10 wt% Ni/AFeO3 (A = Ca, Ce, and Sr) catalysts possess considerable potential for efficient H2 production and stable performance in the steam gasification of WPC.
